data.text: [DOWNLOAD] The updated Regional Economic Outlook for sub-Saharan #Africa discusses policies needed to limit the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and prepare economies for recovery. Download the report here: https://t.co/KitxlVkEUG #IMFAfrica

IMF Managing Director @KGeorgieva will be live with @HarvardBiz where she will discuss the impact of #COVID19 on the global economy and the prospects for recovery. 

Join us on LinkedIn - Tuesday, June 30 at 12 p.m. EST. https://t.co/3dYgWR6jU0 https://t.co/FA1C1p0Re3

#IMF financing will support #Egypt maintain #macroeconomic_stability & continue key structural reforms, by supporting crisis spending on #health & #social_programs & Implementing key reforms to strengthen #transparency, #governance, & #competition. Also https://t.co/aAXQYK25Gh https://t.co/ptzMfdK5Cn

The #Internet remains a luxury: half of the world’s population does not have access. Read our new #IMFBlog to dive into the facts & figures #ChartOfTheWeek https://t.co/hjrGxmsner https://t.co/dERdnP3bRO
6 charts that show sub-Saharan #Africa’s sharpest economic contraction since the 1970s. https://t.co/Rc8pvChOYW #IMFAfrica #COVID19 https://t.co/OL855HbZ5i

How can we “#buildbackbetter” from this crisis?
At the @ndcpartnership conference DMD Zhang outlined 3 priorities for a #GreenRecovery:
1⃣Use public funds wisely
2⃣Put the right price on carbon
3⃣Promote green finance

#PartnershipInAction https://t.co/HhV56ilRUo

IMF’s Selassie: Economic activity in sub-Saharan #Africa this year is now projected to decline by 3.2% – double the contraction anticipated in April. https://t.co/5p1NODrdhy #IMFAfrica  https://t.co/1RX7Je7V3D

How have #COVID19 and containment measures affected economies in sub-Saharan #Africa? Download the updated Regional Economic Outlook report for growth projections and policy priorities for the region: https://t.co/S4tJubPaaj #IMFAfrica  https://t.co/1RX7JepvVb

For the first time, all regions are projected to experience negative growth in 2020. There are, however, substantial differences across individual economies. Find out more about individual growth projections in the latest #WEO. https://t.co/WpXSzg9YxA

How have #COVID19 and containment measures affected economies in sub-Saharan #Africa? Join us today at 8:00 AM EDT (12:00 PM GMT) for a press briefing on the economic outlook for the region. https://t.co/5p1NODrdhy #IMFAfrica https://t.co/1RX7Je7V3D

How is COVID-19 transforming global cooperation, inequality, business, labor markets, geopolitical trends, debt, climate, and the digital economy? Read the F&D article on life post-#COVID19: https://t.co/9YyOY4LPt1 https://t.co/BdBh0sgnxy

#Egypt’s reforms supported by the #IMF financing will help strengthen the frameworks for #public_finances, improve #governance, #transparency, & reduce #barriers_to_competition to ensure a path towards sustainable & inclusive private sector-led #growth https://t.co/AJd4f98m6g https://t.co/i0GnmYKAOW
In a special series of notes, we explore how governments can support people and firms during #COVID19. Download the latest notes here: https://t.co/OKASSzpHeb https://t.co/a20HgdC36d

Tomorrow June 29, at 8:20 AM EDT, Deputy Managing Director Tao Zhang will participate in the @NDCpartnership #Greenrecovery conference. Get the details here:
https://t.co/d7iUZIiTrk

https://t.co/yIMeGmlx8J

How is the IMF responding to the #COVID19 crisis? We are supporting our member countries with policy advice, technical assistance and financial resources. Learn more here: https://t.co/MG5bLfPS1P https://t.co/dCZOgYdUdN

Beyond confronting the health crisis, policymakers must cooperate to resolve #trade and #technology tensions that endanger an eventual recovery from the #COVID19 crisis. Strong multilateral cooperation remains essential on multiple fronts. https://t.co/WpXSzg9YxA #WEO https://t.co/xNObLERLfR
Our #IMFCountryFocus looks at the measures Jamaica is taking to protect lives and livelihoods from the impact of the #COVID19 pandemic. https://t.co/gEMEXxhUNf https://t.co/0cpK3H5Rcu

There are both upside and downside risks to the global outlook and the economic forecast is surrounded by tremendous uncertainty, according to @GitaGopinath. For more details, read the latest #WEO https://t.co/WpXSzg9YxA https://t.co/gtHftKWOq7

Join us tomorrow, Monday, June 29 at 8:00 AM EDT (12:00 PM GMT) for a LIVE press briefing with Abebe Aemro Selassie, Director of the African Department, on the economic outlook for sub-Saharan Africa. Watch here: https://t.co/5p1NODIO96 #IMFAfrica https://t.co/1RX7JepvVb
[REPLAY] Press Briefing: World Economic Outlook, June 2020 Update. https://t.co/WpXSzfSn90 #WEO https://t.co/KR2xinVZZE

The IMF is fully committed to supporting its member countries during the #COVID19 outbreak. Learn more about the IMF's work to address this global challenge here: https://t.co/MmAtAVRwus https://t.co/dQW5p0aLu5

With a deeper than anticipated hit to activity in the first half of the year, growth in #AdvancedEconomies is projected at –8.0% in 2020, 1.9 percentage points lower than forecast in April. In 2021, growth is projected to strengthen to 4.8%. More in #WEO https://t.co/WpXSzg9YxA https://t.co/Oez6mLqjF3
9 recommendations to guide bank supervisors in their response to the pandemic #IMFBlog #COVID19 https://t.co/aijy1pLVXr https://t.co/oYyZqADrGN

Read the latest IMF #WeekendRead newsletter and subscribe for cutting-edge research and analysis of key economic, finance and development issues shaping the world including #COVID19, climate change, corruption, #fintech, trade, inequality and more. https://t.co/1cDVYUGSq0 https://t.co/GqjmNhT9HL

Growth in #EmergingMarket and developing economies is forecast at –3.0% in 2020, 2 percentage points below the April 2020 #WEO forecast. For low-income developing countries, it is projected at –1.0%, some 1.4 percentage points below April. https://t.co/WpXSzg9YxA https://t.co/J4rhtPYYdU

.@GitaGopinath on the forecast for the global economy: the #COVID19 pandemic has had a more negative impact than anticipated, and the recovery is expected to be more gradual. https://t.co/fqM8iURHFv #WEO https://t.co/Gwr6hOXObI

Compared to our April #WEO, we are now projecting a deeper recession in 2020 and a slower recovery in 2021, but a high degree of uncertainty surrounds this forecast. See the latest projections in #IMFBlog https://t.co/fqM8iURHFv https://t.co/TLRnKEmBYV

How has #COVID19 and containment measures affected economies in sub-Saharan Africa? Join us on Monday, June 29 at 8:00 AM EDT (12:00 PM GMT) for a press briefing on the economic outlook for the region. Watch here. https://t.co/5p1NODIO96 #IMFAfrica https://t.co/1RX7JepvVb

Our latest #WEO projects all regions will experience negative growth in 2020, with substantial differences across individual economies. Find out more about regional and country projections in the latest #WEO https://t.co/WpXSzg9YxA https://t.co/B31wfaL8TB

A disconnect between financial markets and the real economy has emerged with the pandemic, posing a risk to the recovery should investors’ attitude change and cause a correction. More in our latest #IMFBlog https://t.co/ABEsjgYcpy  #GFSR https://t.co/cVydBTXqIY

Our previous #WEO forecast in April indicated an unprecedented decline in global activity due to the #COVID19 pandemic. Since then, data releases suggest even deeper downturns than previously projected for several economies. See the projections here: https://t.co/WpXSzg9YxA https://t.co/zL3aPKrOhU

#COVID19 has disrupted tourism and trade, and cut remittances to pacific island countries. Learn more about how the IMF is helping countries weather the crisis. https://t.co/zYc3ucWYOE #IMFCountryFocus https://t.co/qPQYcZ5aZC

Our latest #GFSR research shows that with the easing of global financial conditions, risky asset prices have rebounded since the sharp drop early in the year, while benchmark interest rates have fallen. https://t.co/QrBhHGvzVi #IMFBlog https://t.co/7rWnBhe1tC

The #COVID19 pandemic pushed economies into a #GreatLockdown, which helped contain the virus and save lives, but also triggered the worst recession since the Great Depression. Read @GitaGopinath’s latest blog on the #WEO https://t.co/fqM8iURHFv https://t.co/5hmavw3SGj
REPLAY: Press conference on the latest economic outlook for Latin America and the Caribbean. https://t.co/pm5DtbyP5P

The #COVID19 pandemic has had a more negative impact on activity in the first half of 2020 than anticipated. Global growth is now projected at –4.9% in 2020, 1.9 percentage points below our April 2020 #WEO. Read the latest report https://t.co/WpXSzg9YxA https://t.co/eJyg5ICXeR

#COVID19 has led to a sharp decline in exports, remittances and tourist arrivals in #Myanmar, severely impacting its economy. The IMF Executive Board today has approved US$ 356.5 million in financing to help Myanmar address these challenges. https://t.co/0OSAtglcf7 https://t.co/oQy25OoCzM

A disconnect between financial markets and the real economy has emerged with the pandemic, posing a risk to the recovery should investors’ attitude change and cause a correction. Read our latest #IMFBlog: https://t.co/ABEsjgGB0Y #GFSR https://t.co/zJbwCEq0tU

Worst of the pandemic’s shock to the global economy is probably behind us, but w/ a staggering loss of $12 trillion over 20-21. We now have a better understanding of the crisis but there are still uncertainties before we can come out on the other side in a better overall position https://t.co/CaoiPL2HJv

The #COVID19 pandemic has had a more negative impact than anticipated, and the recovery is projected to be more gradual amidst a lot of uncertainty. What can countries do? #WEO https://t.co/WpXSzg9YxA https://t.co/lXkxnOQkb9

The Caribbean did well in containing the pandemic, but the standstill in tourism will mean a sharp, prolonged recession. Central America also suffers from big drops in trade and remittances. Read the new blog by the IMF Americas director Alejandro Werner: https://t.co/nKBBpnarKm https://t.co/BqvMFiPPIx

How will life look after #COVID19? IMF’s F&D magazine asked 6 leading thinkers to reflect on how the pandemic has changed the world, and what we might expect in the future. Read what they said here: https://t.co/UlZVEKiOBF https://t.co/rMRJ7ZuZYk

IMF’s Werner: To fight the crisis, Latin America needs to spend limited fiscal resources wisely. To prop up economic activity and avoid long-term damage, countries can help companies stay afloat and keep their employees with financing and payroll support. https://t.co/MX33AoVErL https://t.co/vpBlYic7Lr

The IMF expects a contraction of 9.4% in #LatAm & #Caribbean this year—the region’s largest recession on record. As the pandemic subsides, a partial recovery of 3.7% is forecast for 2021. Read new analysis by the IMF Americas director, Alejandro Werner https://t.co/nZLno3PT7F https://t.co/A0Riokl9w7
LIVE NOW: Press conference by Alejandro Werner on the latest economic outlook for Latin America and the Caribbean. https://t.co/FCuLObSPRr

.@KGeorgieva - Discussions with the Lebanese authorities are ongoing, but there is no breakthrough on an IMF financial assistance program yet. #Lebanon’s complex challenges call for unity among all stakeholders and decisive action to restore sustainable, inclusive growth. https://t.co/ax8HAxQF3R

Global public debt as a share of GDP is projected to exceed post WW2 highs this year, in both advanced and emerging market and developing economies. For more details, read #IMFBlog https://t.co/fqM8iURHFv https://t.co/sGa0fawDW1

Advanced and emerging countries alike have been vexed by the challenges of quickly getting financial support to people who lost jobs in the COVID-19 economic crisis. Many governments are using mobile technology and #fintech to help their citizens. https://t.co/eDlUq3UYGo #IMFBlog https://t.co/s6cRSgm0I7

Growth in #AdvancedEconomies is projected at –8.0% in 2020, 1.9 percentage points lower than in the April 2020 WEO. In 2021, growth is projected to strengthen to 4.8%, leaving 2021 GDP for the group about 4% below its 2019 level. More in #WEO https://t.co/WpXSzg9YxA https://t.co/4HpQVBhZfb
